detailedReviewData.description: I found it accidently: this code (now refactored) was IMO really strange (not to say terrible). Two things: - Boolean.valueOf(String) cannot return null - why Boolean was used instead of boolean in all these places, if anyway null was not allowed or even possible.
detailedReviewData.name: Really strange Boolean processing code

versionedLineCommentData.message: test comment

detailedReviewData.description:
Wojtek and Shawn, please take a look and see if everything seems in place.
This change adds two new features - CVS integration and Subversive integration. Both are used in FishEye for now as Team API seems to be not enough.
detailedReviewData.name: PLE-522: FishEye vs Subversive integration

generalCommentData.message: We have to think how to deal with simultaneous dependency on Subclipse and Subversive - if a user just selects all optional integration, he will end up with both SVN plugins installed which makes UI quite confusing - see PLE-529

versionedLineCommentData.message: I am for removing all commented out code which comes from subclipse implementation. Actually I did it last Friday

returning null for unimplemented methods broke some TeamUiUtils methods, which could not handle such return value correctly. They were really fragile anyway and require refactoring (they use somewhat exception-driven flow control, which is bad). Still, more caution is necessary when adding new implementations.

detailedReviewData.description:
Please review my imlementation for editing, posting (publishing drafts) and deleting comments. There are 2 deficiencies: - no special synchronization for actions like publish and remove which run as background jobs and thus can be invoke multiple number of times for single comment. The result is HTTP error nicely handled by Connector. - clearing (resetting) metrics during editing comments does not work well, as remote API/Crucible does something strange with it. Now instead of being just clear they will be "not set" which is apparently different than being "clear".
I've also fixed several bugs in existing implementation.
detailedReviewData.name: PLE-314, PLE-315, PLE-316 implementation ready

generalCommentData.message:
It seems that the changes have somehow disabled the refreshing of the editor: when you make (or change) comments, the editor does not get refreshed anymore (you have to manually hit refresh).
This applies for making the changes in the RichEditor, as well as in the JavaEditor

versionedLineCommentData.message: I think that all our asynchronously displayed error dialogs would in the title indicate where they are coming from. Or do you know of any other style in Eclipse?

generalCommentData.message:
Well, a Status has the plug-in ID, which gives away the source. I don't think having a String constant is a very good choice, mainly because you are using a feature's name as a constant in a plug-in which is part of that feature.
The plug-in only knows of his and it's dependencies, so it should not "assume" it is part of a feature called Atlassian Eclipse Connector. But that are just my humble thoughts, I am not that experienced yet in the whole infrastructure stuff.

I assume that crucible.ui plugin know that it's part of Atlassian Eclipse Connector and cannot live outside it (core plugins could, but for UI I don't think so). There are many plugins constituting this single product. When facing problems, many (most of?) people don't want to see some internal ids, but rather something clear for them which they can use while asking for support. So what in your opinion should be placed in the titile of such error dialog? Still, I am a new guy on this ground and our approach in IntelliJ may not be applicable in Eclipse world. Shawn, Steffen - what do you think?

versionedLineCommentData.message: I am using this silly icon here. If you have anything better to propose, you are welcome

generalCommentData.message: We probably should ask Edwin about icons for some things, like submitting a draft, as well as editing / removing comments

versionedLineCommentData.message:
checkstyle error here...
And I think the reason why the formatter is not wrapping this line is because each condition is nested in the previous one, and the line wraping only wraps conditions of a single level. The whole condition is not really readable anyway, so I would vote for cleaning it up a bit (maybe make one or two booleans extra which then get combined to the isModified (it would make it a lot more readable and comprehensable)
P.S.: I can finally use defect :)

generalCommentData.message:
Yeah, it's defect of Eclipse formatter :)
I'll simplify it anyway.
Well, not sure if it is actually a defect. I think it would look very weird to wrap those nested conditions...so it seems to be an implicit checkStyle :)
fixed with you - on your laptop

versionedLineCommentData.message: just a hint: we have a CrucibleUiUtil.getCurrentUser method (which means my above comment is obsolete)
Not sure, but I think this method should probably go somewhere else (maybe in the CrucibleUiUtil as something like isCommentEditable (which includes removing/posting it)

generalCommentData.message: I've extracted this method to CrucibleUiUtil and refactored it to use getCurrentUser()

versionedLineCommentData.message: as we discussed it on Friday, I've changed the names of these buttons

I noticed that in some places our error handling is far from perfect, e.g. a dialog is shown which does not even suggest what given problem is related to. This is my approach. Let me know what you think about it.

generalCommentData.message:
The weird error dialog is shown if a Job returns an error state. That's why we always return OK_Status, and in case we actually want to know about the real status, we keep a real status as field and have a getter to retrieve it.
Bottom-line I learned: never let a Job return the error status ;)

What I mean here, is that we sometimes lose information: which job/task caused an exception (e.g. update of what review) + we only either log using StatusHandler or only show error dialog. Thanks for the warning. Shawn says exactly the same.
If you have multiple tasks you can use Multistatus to collect all the stati and log this one (you will get the expandable log entry then)

versionedLineCommentData.message: You could use your neat CrucibleUiUtil.getClient there I guess
I extracted it from two child classes and put here.
Could you please make a testcase for that in CrucibleUiUtilTest?

generalCommentData.message: we can sit on it tomorrow and pair-program
let's do that. remind me please ;)

versionedLineCommentData.message: this is needed if we want actions in nested parts to notify our listener. Without it our tooltip was not hidden when playing with nested comments/replies

generalCommentData.message:
I don't think I understand what this is for / why it is needed...
If Shawn does, great :) if not, I could need some explanation please

As far as I understand, we hide our dialog by implementing IReviewActionListener and invoking close() when action is about to run (actionAboutToRun() method). By default the listener is unset (null) and till now we haven't been propagating the listener (which invokes close()) to child comment parts. The result: on my computer after e.g. pressing edit comment, the tooltip did not disappear and collided with the dialog.

versionedLineCommentData.message: this is quite exact copy of CrucibleAddCommentDialog. What be great to merge it, but before that cleanup is required

detailedReviewData.description: my quick, dirty and naive implementation (to make it real for 1.0) of Crucible servers being also FishEye servers. This is a lot of shortcuts here. For more discussion (rationale for this implementation) and future plans see PLE-489
detailedReviewData.name: PLE-489 Crucible integrated with FishEye

generalCommentData.message:
Solution is proven to work.
However I am not sure if having a split between crucible and fisheye makes much sense. Since Crucible can exist without Fisheye and vice versa on the server side, either we can mirror that on the client (by having no dependency), or we just put all into one plugin. But then I do not see that obvious gain we would have from merging now either. So it seems it should stay like that for now. If problems surface or other ties between the two plug-ins need to be made I think I would favour merging them though.

detailedReviewData.description:
We are able to connect to Crucible/Fisheye and retrieve code reviews without issue. We can open a code review in the Code Review Editor but when selecting the "open revision" or "open compare" link for the code to be reviewed from within the Code Review Editor we get the following error:
"Unable to open file. (or in the case of compare: Unable to compare revisions). Following exception was catched:
Could not locate resource. (path to file in SVN)"
it suggested looking at the Eclipse Error Log for more details. The Eclipse error log states:
"Unable to determine if file is in sync. Trying to open remote file.
An exception stack trace is not available."
detailedReviewData.name: PLE-589: Error trying to open file from Crucible Code Review Editor

generalCommentData.message: I don't fully understand the background of this issue and your solution here. We have to talk about it when you are here. Still, I had some comments.
The problem was that if the oldRevisionString was empty SVNRevision.fromString was throwing an exception and the whole execution was aborted.

versionedLineCommentData.message: This version should probably be pulled up to TeamResourceConnector interface.

this method is IMO ugly. It should return IEditorPart rather than Status. Only in case of failure CoreException will carry the Status. Could you give reasons for desiging this method in such strange way?

generalCommentData.message: Well, that's a leftover. Cleaned this up.

versionedLineCommentData.message: I'm for removing this method totally from TeamResourceConnectors.

generalCommentData.message: would you like then open compare editor in one common way, where TeamResourceConnectors would be only responsible for providing data?

This method implements a logic that should be IMO handled by the caller - if there's no file in newFilePath and newRevisionString it tries to look up it under oldFilePath and oldRevisionString. Also arrangment of arguments can be misleading.

versionedLineCommentData.message: This logic pulled up to the caller.

generalCommentData.message: Wojtek -- what config did the other users have?

versionedLineCommentData.message: Strictly, this is not required, since if you get to here, you will reset the count on the next pass through the while loop

generalCommentData.message:
oh yes, you are right. But I've made mistake. The line: int numExceptionsCaught = 0; // retry counter
should be 2 lines before - i.e. before while(!stopping). Now it does not make any sense (numExceptionsCaught will never be greater than 1)

versionedLineCommentData.message:
You could combine these as if (++numExceptionsCaught > 50) ...
but that is probably a personal preference.

generalCommentData.message: In general I try to avoid such constructs and idioms to make the code clearer for newbies (not everybody has been programming in Java for 10 years or more as we here) and easier for debugging.

versionedLineCommentData.message: I wonder if this should be debug level logging. Since you are going to retry, there is probably no benefit in logging this as an error until you decide that you can no longer retry (as you do below)

generalCommentData.message: I would change it to warn(). Still it would be good to see what is going on wrong even without --debug. All right?

versionedLineCommentData.message: This can be changed to foreach and genericised.

generalCommentData.message: sure. I wanted to minimize the changes in this code, so I did not decide to change getWatchesForRep() to return a strongly typed list.

detailedReviewData.description:
While recently fighting with some Crucible REST API issues, I decided to add to RemoteApiException an additional field: server stack trace. Will hopefully help you to detect whether the problem lies on your side or not. Sometimes even may be a hint why HTTP 500 occurred (i.e. why server failed - e.g. due to some null parameter). I display now this info in IntelliJ in every place where RemoteApiException is handled by error message (when user clicks on Details button).
Feel free to use it also in Eclipse.
detailedReviewData.name: Server stack traces now available in RemoteApiException

versionedLineCommentData.message: when there is stack trace info available in server response (Crucible normally sends it automatically on every unexpected runtime exception), getServerStackTrace will be non-null.

detailedReviewData.name: PLE-573: Refactoring to ITeamResourceConnector and fix for endless loop in New Crucible Review

detailedReviewData.description: having this debug info makes sense (if again our customer encounter notification problems). To keep logs clean, I moved logging of information (just the single invocation) that thread is alive and just process notifications to a separate logger. I hope it makes sense. Customer can be easily instructed to modify log4j.xml and set threshold to DEBUG.

detailedReviewData.description:
Here's a review for recent ACC changes done to fix notification for comments.
Code was simplified. Unfortunately some parts work differently now. So please try to understand this change and think about consequences this could introduce. If you think something might be broken please tell me.
So, differences are: * isShortEquals ignores changes in general comments * isFilesEqual returns true if general comments are different * change in general comments doesn't trigget review data changed notification (but triggers comment notifications)

This code made our tests stall - modal dialogs poped out and no one closed them during tests leaving Eclipse waiting for user input.
I fixed it by adding suppressConfigurationWizards into this condition.

generalCommentData.message: thanks! I completely forgot about compatibility with our integration tests in headless mode. Is this suppressConfiguratoinWizards() the only method we should examine or are there any other cosher ways to detect whether we are running tests or not?
Use only this one and update it when necessary. This one is used across ACE.

detailedReviewData.description: I used the opportunity of fixing several Bamboo related issues to refactor the code related to BambooView - especially all these actions which used mercilessly copied and paste code. Take a look at these changes and let me know if you have any questions or further ideas on how to improve it.
detailedReviewData.name: PLE-696, ACC-50, PLE-701: A lot of changes on Bamboo side in Eclipse

generalCommentData.message:
I also changed our Bamboo build model on Eclipse side and introduced class which combines together TaskRepository and BambooBuild - thus we can get rid of all these error-prone (what if Task repo URL has changed meanwhile) invocations to retrieve TaskRepository basing on given server url as returned in BambooBuild.
I also resigned from using rotating throbber as: - it causes a lot of problems (and performance impact) while refreshing Bamboo view - I don't think it feels "Eclipsy" Instead I use italics to denote plans in an interim state + I replaced icons with regular text in State column.
Wojtek, my time on the contract is already exceeded, so I wont be able to process this big review.

versionedLineCommentData.message: You assume here it's not null, are getBuild(), getBuild().getPlanKey() marked as not null?

generalCommentData.message: yep, everything in this chain is NotNull. I'll add missing annotation (there was only assertion in the constructor) go getBuild() in this very class

versionedLineCommentData.message: using inheritance just to add some util methods is evil. Especially if those methods (like getImage() here) serve totally different purpose then the original class: pure UI vs. UI-independent build data).
ttest
test

detailedReviewData.description:
RepositoryConfigurationAction can use org.eclipse.mylyn.tasks.ui.command.AddTaskRepository as command contribution to open the newRepositoryWizard instead of invoking mylyn internals.
Changed code so it uses command defined by Mylyn. But to be honest I don't like it. I'm for using Mylyn internal API here (as it was before my change) because if it API changes will find it sooner (at compile time). So I will happily revert this change :-)
I committed it only to share with you how we can invoke commands from our code. Also just to show how much this sucks ;-)
I added Thomas because he was a reporter for PLE-440.
Feel free to say that this code sucks and we should revert it to internal API :-)
detailedReviewData.name: PLE-440: Replace addTaskRepository call by command contribution

generalCommentData.message: I have no strong preference. However I would love to learn from Shawn or Thomas if and how one can in general attach Eclipse actions or commands/handlers to hand-made built SWT dialogs,views, etc. Here we are creating SWT Link in Bamboo view and ideally one could just register Mylyn action/command in this place (when user clicks on it). Your thoughts guys are appreciated.

detailedReviewData.name: PL-1240 - Share credentials across different servers

generalCommentData.message:
It is really pity that you did not think about discussing such quite serious design changes in ACC before you started the implementation. I was totally astonished when I saw it commited.
I have serious concerns with the current approach, unless you can convince me.
I am currently responsible for maintaining commons in the shape which is acceptable for IntelliJ, Eclipse and probably incoming Netbeans. Such changes must be coordinated in advance.
I am totally open to any real improvement, but I tend to think that these changes are not in this category. Reasons: * ServerCfg and descendant classes were designed as simple configuration bean - no logic at all. Now they began to "think" about default user * References to UserCfg make ServerCfg even more fragile (as far as equals() and hashcode() is concerned) and not thread safe * We have already a lot of problems with sessions which use mutable objects which leads to memory leaks. Ultimately Server object passed to any method of facades should contain just username and password. Nothing more. These changes go in just the opposite way * As our configuration requirements are getting more complex, it's time for more serious refactoring and splitting classes used for persisting configuration (ServerCfg - they should contain info like whether to use default credentials or not, but definitely they should not reference default user configuration) and classes used by facades. When we are calling facades, we should map such configuration classes to server classes * sharing info about default credentials in public xml files has not sense.
More about it when I'll be back in Gdańsk.
We will discuss this next week after Easter

versionedLineCommentData.message: please notice that we do not use Java camelCase style here, but dash delimited names. This problem is repeated in many places. You have to configure XStream appropriately.

I think that this is going to far... Our ServerCfg objects become too intelligent. I don't think that putting everything into ServerCfg objects is a good design decision. ServerCfg (and Server) should be as thin as possible.
do not use * imports
do not use * imports
makes no sense to share it in XML file
do not use * imports
I think we should remove it from here and totally change design of this stuff
boolean flag makes sense, but defaultUser IMO does not. It makes these objects even more fragile and less reusable between various platforms
this flag in shared XML files does not make sense
do not use * imports
IMO it should be here at all. Why: we can talk about it in detail when I'll be back in Gdańsk

detailedReviewData.description:
Guys,
While restoring clean CI environment on Bamboo, I went through Pazu code (very superficially only). I found a few problems which deserve mentioning.
detailedReviewData.name: Food for thought after initial phase of checkstyle cleanup

versionedLineCommentData.message:
FutureTask does not make sense here (and in 4 other places in the same class): - you don't synchronize on completion - you don't want to know the result
Probably some thread pool should be used here.
This enum has been greatly simplified. Do not overuse possibility to have abstract methods and then different implementation for each enum instance. It's often unnecessary and makes the code bloated.
I think that mixing business logic with typical UI dialog in one class is not good. Also whole file becomes bloated. Dialog moved to a separate file in idea tree
ThreadLocal is generified! Wrap it instead of accessing publicly from outside (with ugly casting as it used to be before)
again: bloated enum. After shorthening about 3 times shorter
What is the GetUserName dialog? Is it some IDEA thing or have you generified getting user name in the whole plugin?

generalCommentData.message: It's Pazu dialog. It was just only bad named. I did not do anything more than renaming it.

in that case, I am not sure if you did the right thing. I have never seen the GetUserName dialog before. Does it allow you to enter free-text user name? Because that's what's required for JIRA. In the future though, the user name dialog for JIRA will have to be tied to JIRA API to retrieve existing user names - so I am not sure if it wouldn't be more prudent to keep them separate

versionedLineCommentData.message: WARNING: Why "10" was here? Do we really want to skip for 10 characters?
this logic is execute twice. Moved to a small util method
static methods ARE final I know that this code has been borrowed, but anyway...
Why didn't you remove them?

generalCommentData.message: because below there was temporarily commented code (a lot of it) and it will not work without these imports one day, when the author will decide to use it (and uncomment his code).

versionedLineCommentData.message: Whole dialog removed to GetUserNameDialog
QUESTION: are we sure that "/" should be there and not File.separator ? Will it work for Windows?

there are too many veryLongNamesOfPropertiesAndTheirGetters which result in many places in lines having 200 characters instead of 100. I recommend using something shorter (but do not go too far - @Lukasz & Perl). ;)
why such method signature has to occupy 4 lines instead of 1? Are we paid per LOC? :) The smaller code, the better (and less error-prone)

generalCommentData.message: this code has been stolen verbatim from intellijad - RTFM

versionedLineCommentData.message: this is the second time the same logic is used

Potential NPE here (IDEA even warns about it). table.getSelectedObject() returns null if notihing is selected (e.g. something has been just deselected). The same bugixed in several places. QUESTION: Do we silently stop processing even if adapter == null?

generalCommentData.message: Don't worry - if nothing is selected then the code in question cannot be executed (actions are disabled).

@Janusz: not true, actually. Sometimes it takes up to a SECOND for IDEA to update the action state - so it is quite possible to trigger an action just before it is updated. Maybe it is difficult in this case, but believe me - there is somebody in the world who will manage :-)

@Slawek - I think you are almost right, but not quite. The thing is - all actions start off as disabled and only become enabled once you select some row in JIRA tool window. AFAIK (am I wrong here?), there is no way to remove selection from JIRA issue table once youhave selected something, so there is no danger for this reference to ever become null. So unless my assumption here is wrong, the check for null is unnecessary and slows the code down :P
remove selection - refresh, change page not likely to trigger in a popup menu (although possible), but in the future someone will make a toolbar icon using the same code...

versionedLineCommentData.message: EMPTY_LIST is in generic world type-unsafe! use emptyList() instead

detailedReviewData.description:
@Shawn: can you comment on using a job as a handler for New task from failed build action. What I'm asking is - using a job as a response to user action is a questionable decision for me - as this makes the whole process asynchronous. I understand that using asynchronous communication in Eclipse is a common and advised solution. But do you feel that in this case it's a good decision?
Would it be better to make this a synchronous operation - user selects this actions, modal pop-up with progress is showed (Downloading details from Bamboo server...), then after details are downloaded New Task dialog is opened. What do you think? And if you think that this would be a better solution can you advise me on which tools, classes, interfaces I should use? Or can you point me to some example?
I will appreciate feedback.
Thanks in advance.
detailedReviewData.name: PLE-299: Action: create Task from failed Build

versionedLineCommentData.message: I agree that the Job is too quiet for user interaction. What you could do is use a ProgressDialog as the CrucibleAddCommentDialog does, and then you can use an IRunnableWithProgress so that the user can see what is happening.
I think that this class deserves a few unit tests, e.g. getCommentSnippet would throw new NPE.

detailedReviewData.description: We want to distinguish between error in ITeamResouceConnector implementation and unsupported action. Introduce null to signal that operation is not supported. Handle this in TeamUiUtils.

generalCommentData.message: Technically these changes are OK, but I feel that we should rather improve and use canHandle() method rather than returning null for not supported files/resources.

versionedLineCommentData.message: I think that @NotNull result would be better here. If repositoryUrl is bad I would throw an expection
I think that ultimately if canHandleFile returns true then we should just assume that this filePath is really handled by this connector and not by the other

Accidental or too eager Ctrl+D :) ?

detailedReviewData.description:
To reproduce:
- create two post commit reviews from the same changeset (one file in the changeset is enough) - add line comment to the file from review1 - activate the review and open file with comment (you will see annotation in the editor) - open the same file from the review2 (the file has no comments in that review) but do not activate review2 - you will see warning that file will not be annotated (because review2 is not active) but the file will have annotation (*it is taken from active review1 which has the same file*)
The problem here is that annotation model does not take file info from the currently open review (review associated with open file) but uses util method which searches active review for currently open file (by accident active review1 has the same file as review2).
detailedReviewData.name: PLE-710: Having two reviews with the same file causes a problem
